results.title: The Chelsea Flower Show
results.brief_description: It was in 1913 that the Royal Horticultural Society moved its Great Spring Show from the Temple Gardens to the Royal Chelsea Hospital. This commemorative video looks back over the last 75 golden years, and illustrates this fascinating history with period photographs, film and music. Rated: G

results.title: The Chateau country
results.creator_credit: Vavin and French Government Tourist Office
results.brief_description: A tour of the Renaissance castles of the Loire Valley. Rambouillet, summer residence of the French President; Blois, with its historical associations; Chateau Renault, court of the Valois and Orleans kings; Amboise with the chapel of St Hubert; Chinon, associated with Joan of Arc; and much more.

results.title: The Charwoman
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Roger Blais and Leonard Forest
results.brief_description: At daybreak, while the rest of Ottawa sleeps, a small army of workers is astir, setting in order the houses of government for the business of the day. This film presents a whimsical sketch of a charwoman who knows every nook and cranny of the stately House of Commons and who dreams wistfully of the brighter future her young daughter may have as a result of her labors with mop and pail.

results.title: The Charter of the United Nations
results.creator_credit: Crown Film Unit and Alexander Shaw
results.brief_description: An explanation of the structure and the purposes of the United Nations Organization, showing the General Assembly, the Security Council, and the various commissions set up to further the cause of world peace and well-being. Commentary by Francis Williams.

results.title: The Charter
results.creator_credit: United Nations. Office of Public Information
results.brief_description: The Charter and the main organs of the United Nations. Traces the historical background to the Charter, the broad principles laid down in its preamble and shows scenes of the meeting at which it was signed. Describes the membership and functions of the General Assembly, the Security Council, the Economic and Social Council, the Trusteeship Council, the International Court of Justice and the United Nations Secretariat. Beautifully photographed and interspersed with newsreels and stock footage of both world wars. Compiled by V.R. Sarma; commentary by Alistair Cooke and Michael Allinson.

results.title: The Charm of Ulster
results.brief_description: Tours the six Northern Ireland counties. Explores the strange rock formations of the Giant’s Causeway, the walled city and port of Londonderry, and the great port and shipbuilding centre of Belfast. Shows the golf and motor racing for which Ulster is famous; also visits St Patrick’s tomb at Downpatrick, and the romantic town of Enniskillen.

results.title: The Charm of Britain
results.creator_credit: Seven Network Limited (Australia) and Greg Grainger
results.brief_description: Britain in the 1990’s is in a period of transition. There’s division about the future of the Royal Family and doubts about the country’s closer links with Europe. Many in Scotland would like to become independent. The Welsh also want greater autonomy in running their own affairs. But through it all, the British remain British - and custodians of one of the most beautiful islands on earth. Less than a thousand kilometres long from top to bottom, and home to almost 60 million people, Great Britain may not be the world power it once was, but in terms of history and culture, it still has few equals. Our intention is to travel the length of this amazingly diverse country, observing the growing independence of many of its regions, sampling its rich traditions, as we discover for ourselves “The Charm of Britain”.

results.title: The Charge of the Light Brigade
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures and Michael Curtiz
results.brief_description: Alfred Tennyson’s epic poem about the fated charge by the Light Brigade at Balaklava in the Crimean War, immortalised a military legend. This is a fictionalised acccount of this suicidal charge. Major Geoffrey Vickers (Errol Flynn) leads the 27th Lancers against Indian Chieftan Surat Khan who has joined forces with the Russians. Within this scenario, Vickers is involved in a tumultous love triangle with his brother and beautiful fiance (Olivia De Haviland). Directed by Michael Curtiz who also directed “Casablanca” and “The Adventures of Robin Hood.” The classic charge at the film’s conclusion is an inspired piece of filming.

results.title: The Charge at Beersheba
results.creator_credit: Australia. Dept. of Defence and Greg Parry
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sentinel”.
The last great cavalry charge in history, at Beersheba (Israel) in 1917, by the AIF Light Horse, is still celebrated today. The charge is regarded as an achievement in the history of the 12/16 Hunter River Lancers, based at Tamworth in New South Wales. The unit, comprising Army Reservists, has strong traditions spanning a period of almost one hundred years. The regiment celebrates the charge annually with a formal dinner. The traditions of the 12/16 HRL are upheld by an active Regimental Association formed by veterans of past campaigns. Because of the keen interest in horsemanship displayed by the veterans, many of the Army Reservists in the regiment have taken to learning the skills associated with Light Horse cavalry. Commentary by Peter Gwynne, cinematography by Phil Hobson.

results.title: The Chaplin review
results.creator_credit: First National Pictures and Charles Chaplin
results.brief_description: This video features two Chaplin favourites: Shoulder arms - Is an unusual mixture of realism and fantasy with Chaplin’s characteristic touches of slapstick, satire, irony and pathos. It has been suggested that Chaplin’s film provides a truer picture of World War I than most of the more ambitious dramas. The Pilgrim - Escaped convict Chaplin lands himself in all manner of situations when he disguises himself as a preacher. Silent films with English intertitles.
